ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained specific knowledge of some of the literatures and motifs of the British otherworld tradition.

I learned a great deal of breadth about medieval literature, and new ways to interpret broad themes and motifs as they carry over through many different texts, in particular otherworlds and dream vision motifs.
I learned how to evaluate texts written in the Medieval Era and patterns among descriptions of otherworld visions across countries and time.
Learned about classical, Christian, and local British Otherworld folklore
I learned about medieval tradition and essay writing skills

I learned more than I could ever imagine about medieval England, Christianity, and death! I loved how this class allowed us to consider theology, morality, philosophy, and history alongside literature making the texts we were reading feel relevant and allowing us to analyze them from all different angles. Aside from that, reading these texts was most of all fun wild, fantastical, adventurous. All the things I love about literature!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course didn't really have any weaknesses. It was very manageable and well-structured, in addition to being interesting!

This course excelled at dipping the students' toes into a wide variety of different texts and bringing new insightful ways of reading those texts into each course. The only improvement I would consider recommending is swapping out some of the more similar early Latin vision texts for a wider variety, although there may also be a benefit to having to read closely similar texts or even translations and pick out the differences.

While I thought Professor Thorbury and my TA were great, I think the overall structure of the course is a little confusing. It already assumes a significant amount of religious knowledge and we read a lot of short excerpts from things that I felt were often a bit decontextualized. I would've preferred to read fewer but longer texts that we could have dived into more.

Strengths: organized lectures, good feedback, engaging assignments
Weaknesses: extensive workload near the end of the class

We had way too many essays during the course. We had two midterms, a final essay, and a final exam that was essay-based. I just ran out of ideas! I had nothing else to talk about and it was exhausting by the end.
Strengths: very engaged, knowledgeable, and creative instructors. Could be improved by perhaps including more translations and discussions on translations for Middle English texts

I actually thought the reading load was perfect in this class. I think it isn't useful when reading assignments are always hundreds of pages a week, because that means they oftentimes cannot be completed by every student and everyone ends up on a different page. This class had a great, moderate reading load which meant I almost always felt prepared for our discussions and managed time to properly listen and make notes for the prerecorded lectures. I definitely enjoyed the structure, content, and teaching of the class.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was formatted very well for the virtual setting. By making one of the seminar sessions into recorded lectures, I was able to learn about the materials in more depth, and the virtual sessions did not become overwhelming.

The combination of recorded lectures and live "leminars" really made this course effective at addressing both the necessary interpretative questions and also allowing for fruitful discussion of the texts from the students.
The course was very engaging even over Zoom.
The recorded lectures were accommodating. The live lectures and sections could have been made more accommodating by being recorded.

The discussion sections were engaging, and the format of recorded lectures (various sections) was helpful. The combination of both a final project and a final exam did make the last few weeks of the semester much more stressful than the earlier months.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you're interested in Medieval literature, then this class would probably be a good fit for you. If you don't have any familiarity with literature from this time period, however, I might start with a different Medieval lit. class and see if you like it before taking this class.

I would definitely recommend this course, specifically for students like me, who need to fulfill the medieval requirement for the English major but don't have a huge interest in this time period. Learning about otherworlds and afterlives in this class was really cool!

I would highly recommend this course to any student who wants to dive into the world of medieval literature. While there are some essential medieval texts that were not covered in this course, the most exciting texts in the course were those that most students would not encounter elsewhere, and are tons of fun to read and study.

I would recommend this course to a student who is really interested in the specific topic it addresses (otherworld visions in British medieval literature). Otherwise, it's a lot of short readings and a significant amount of work.
The class is a very traditional English course and occasionally felt a bit outdated given the climate of 2020 and 2021.
Only if you're interested in medieval, british, christian visions of the heaven/hell, or you need the medieval english requirement. Otherwise, maybe not.
Yes! Its a fun, engaging class and medieval credit for the English major.

Originally, I was not looking forward to my medieval English requirement, and anticipated a boring class filled with incomprehensible Middle English. Instead, I got one of my favorite classes of my Yale career. The readings were incredibly rich and unlike most texts I had ever read before, I learned to read (and actually like?!) Middle English, and the class combined literature with history and philosophy in such an engaging way. Professor Thornbury's lectures provided such a useful roadmap through which to understand these texts, and we always had the opportunity in seminar and section to ask our questions and direct the discussion to what we thought was most interesting. I would most definitely recommend this course to another student.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: In addition to live virtual lectures, we also had recorded lectures and section.
One class period per week came in the form of recorded lectures.
The course was a live virtual lecture with live virtual discussion sections and supplementary recorded lectures.
Recorded lecture, live virtual lecture, virtual section
Live virtual seminar, recorded lectors, live section.
Recorded lecture with a live whole class virtual discussion and a smaller virtual section each week
recorded lectures, live lectures, and live discussion sections
Recorded lectures, weekly seminar and weekly sections.
